themes.label: Agonistic / Victory Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The inscription commemorates a military victory by the King of Aksum over the Bougaites, detailing the capture and submission of the enemy.
themes.quote: τοὺς πολεμῆσαι καὶ παραδεδωκότων αὐτῶν ὑποτάξαντες αὐτοὺς ἤγαγον πρὸς ἡμᾶς

themes.label: Votive Dedications
themes.rationale: The king dedicates statues of gold, silver, and bronze, as well as the stele itself, to the god Ares (Mahrem) as an act of thanksgiving for his victory.
themes.quote: ὑπὲρ δὲ εὐχαριστίας τοῦ ἐμοῦ γεννήσαντος ἀνικήτου Ἄρεως ἀνεθήκαμεν ἀνδριάντα χρύσαιον ἕνα καὶ ἀργύραιον ἕνα καὶ χαλκαίους τρεῖς

themes.label: Protective Charms
themes.rationale: The text concludes with a formal curse intended to protect the monument from damage or desecration, invoking the god of heaven and earth.
themes.quote: εἴ τις οὖν τοῦτον ἀδικήσαι βουληθῇ ἐξολεθρεύσει αὐτὸν ὁ θεὸς τοῦ οὐρανοῦ καὶ τῆς γῆς

themes.label: Edicts and Ordinances
themes.rationale: The inscription records royal decrees concerning the resettlement of the defeated Bougaites and the specific provisions (rations) allocated to them.
themes.quote: μετοικίσαντες αὐτοὺς κατεστήσαμεν εἴς τινα τόπον τῆς ἡμετέρας χώρας καλούμενον Μάτλια καὶ ἐκελεύσαμεν αὐτοὺς πάλιν ἀννωνεύεσθαι

themes.label: Commemorative Monuments
themes.rationale: The text explicitly identifies the object as a stele set up to commemorate the king's deeds and his relationship with the divine.

themes.label: Stele
themes.rationale: The inscription refers to itself as a 'stele' (στήλην).

themes.label: Other Stone
themes.rationale: Aksumite stelae of this period were typically carved from local stone such as basalt or granite, which falls under the 'Other Stone' category in the provided taxonomy.

themes.label: Fragmentary
themes.rationale: The text contains several lacunae and reconstructed sections, indicating the physical state of the inscription is not fully intact.
themes.quote: θε[ ὸς] ... π ρ[χ] ... ν γ ζ ντων

rationale: This inscription is a major historical document from the Aksumite Empire, written in Greek. It records the military campaigns of King Ezana against the Bougaites. It follows a standard royal Aksumite pattern: a list of titles, a narrative of the campaign and the humane treatment/resettlement of the captives, a dedication of statues and a stele to the god Ares (the Greek equivalent of the Aksumite war god Mahrem), and a closing curse to protect the monument. The use of Greek reflects the international status of Aksum in Late Antiquity.
